snp3.7:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā aṅguttarāpesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi yena āpaṇaṃ nāma aṅguttarāpānaṃ nigamo tadavasari.
snp3.7:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants in the land of the Aṅguttarāpans when he arrived at a town of theirs named Āpaṇa.

snp3.7:1.4.pli: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito aṅguttarāpesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi āpaṇaṃ anuppatto.
snp3.7:1.4.eng: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.

snp3.7:1.5.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

snp3.7:1.6.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
snp3.7:1.6.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

snp3.7:1.7.pli: So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
snp3.7:1.7.eng: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

snp3.7:1.8.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
snp3.7:1.8.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

snp3.7:1.9.pli: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī”ti.
snp3.7:1.9.eng: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

snp3.7:2.1.pli: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
snp3.7:2.1.eng: So Keṇiya approached the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
snp3.7:2.1.comm: Keṇiya features also in the Vinaya, where at this point he offered the Buddha and the Sangha a drink in the evening, reasoning that the Brahmanical sages of the past did likewise (Kd 6:35.1.2). As a result, the Buddha allowed fruit juice and other drinks in the evening.

snp3.7:2.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
snp3.7:2.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.

snp3.7:2.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho keṇiyaṃ jaṭilaṃ bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
snp3.7:2.3.eng: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.

snp3.7:2.4.pli: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.7:2.4.eng: Then he said to the Buddha,

snp3.7:2.5.pli: “adhivāsetu me bhavaṃ gotamo svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
snp3.7:2.5.eng: “Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”

snp3.7:2.6.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā keṇiyaṃ jaṭilaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.7:2.6.eng: When he said this, the Buddha said to him,

snp3.7:2.7.pli: “mahā kho, keṇiya, bhikkhusaṅgho aḍḍhateḷasāni bhikkhusatāni; tvañca brāhmaṇesu abhippasanno”ti.
snp3.7:2.7.eng: “The Saṅgha is large, Keṇiya; there are 1,250 mendicants. And you are devoted to the brahmins.”

snp3.7:3.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho keṇiyo jaṭilo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.7:3.1.eng: For a second time, Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering.

snp3.7:3.2.pli: “kiñcāpi, bho gotama, mahā bhikkhusaṅgho aḍḍhateḷasāni bhikkhusatāni, ahañca brāhmaṇesu abhippasanno;
snp3.7:3.2.eng: “Never mind that the Saṅgha is large, with 1,250 mendicants, and that I am devoted to the brahmins.

snp3.7:3.3.pli: adhivāsetu me bhavaṃ gotamo svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
snp3.7:3.3.eng: Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”

snp3.7:3.4.pli: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā keṇiyaṃ jaṭilaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.7:3.4.eng: And for a second time, the Buddha gave the same reply.

snp3.7:3.5.pli: “mahā kho, keṇiya, bhikkhusaṅgho aḍḍhateḷasāni bhikkhusatāni; tvañca brāhmaṇesu abhippasanno”ti.

snp3.7:4.1.pli: Tatiyampi kho keṇiyo jaṭilo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.7:4.1.eng: For a third time, Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering.

snp3.7:4.2.pli: “kiñcāpi, bho gotama, mahā bhikkhusaṅgho aḍḍhateḷasāni bhikkhusatāni, ahañca brāhmaṇesu abhippasanno,
snp3.7:4.2.eng: “Never mind that the Saṅgha is large, with 1,250 mendicants, and that I am devoted to the brahmins.

snp3.7:4.3.pli: adhivāsetu me bhavaṃ gotamo svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
snp3.7:4.3.eng: Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”

snp3.7:4.5.pli: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena sako assamo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mittāmacce ñātisālohite āmantesi:
snp3.7:4.5.eng: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Keṇiya got up from his seat and went to his own hermitage. There he addressed his friends and colleagues, relatives and kin,

snp3.7:4.6.eng: “My friends and colleagues, relatives and kin: please listen!

snp3.7:4.7.pli: samaṇo me gotamo nimantito svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena,
snp3.7:4.7.eng: The ascetic Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha has been invited by me for tomorrow’s meal.

snp3.7:4.8.eng: Please help me out with the manual preparations.”
snp3.7:4.8.comm: “Manual preparations” is kāyaveyyāvaṭikaṁ. Ten kinds of service are enumerated in the Jain Tattvārthasūtra 9.24.

snp3.7:4.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho keṇiyassa jaṭilassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā keṇiyassa jaṭilassa paṭissutvā appekacce uddhanāni khaṇanti, appekacce kaṭṭhāni phālenti, appekacce bhājanāni dhovanti, appekacce udakamaṇikaṃ patiṭṭhāpenti, appekacce āsanāni paññāpenti.
snp3.7:4.9.eng: “Yes, worthy sir,” they replied. Some dug ovens, some chopped wood, some washed dishes, some set out a water jar, and some spread out seats.

snp3.7:4.10.pli: Keṇiyo pana jaṭilo sāmaṃyeva maṇḍalamāḷaṃ paṭiyādeti.
snp3.7:4.10.eng: Meanwhile, Keṇiya set up the pavilion himself.

snp3.7:5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena selo brāhmaṇo āpaṇe paṭivasati, tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo, tīṇi ca māṇavakasatāni mante vāceti.
snp3.7:5.1.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Sela was residing in Āpaṇa. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. He knew them word-by-word, and their grammar. He was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. And he was teaching three hundred young students to recite the hymns.

snp3.7:6.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena keṇiyo jaṭilo sele brāhmaṇe abhippasanno hoti.
snp3.7:6.1.eng: And at that time Keṇiya was devoted to Sela.

snp3.7:6.2.pli: Atha kho selo brāhmaṇo tīhi māṇavakasatehi parivuto jaṅghāvihāraṃ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno yena keṇiyassa jaṭilassa assamo tenupasaṅkami.
snp3.7:6.2.eng: Then Sela, while going for a walk escorted by the three hundred young students, approached Keṇiya’s hermitage.

snp3.7:6.3.pli: Addasā kho selo brāhmaṇo keṇiyassa jaṭilassa assame appekacce uddhanāni khaṇante …pe… appekacce āsanāni paññapente, keṇiyaṃ pana jaṭilaṃ sāmaṃyeva maṇḍalamāḷaṃ paṭiyādentaṃ.
snp3.7:6.3.eng: He saw the preparations going on,

snp3.7:6.5.pli: “kiṃ nu kho bhoto keṇiyassa āvāho vā bhavissati, vivāho vā bhavissati, mahāyañño vā paccupaṭṭhito, rājā vā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro nimantito svātanāya saddhiṃ balakāyenā”ti?
snp3.7:6.5.eng: “Keṇiya, is your son or daughter being married? Or are you setting up a big sacrifice? Or has King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha been invited for tomorrow’s meal?”

snp3.7:7.1.pli: “Na me, bho sela, āvāho vā bhavissati vivāho vā, nāpi rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro nimantito svātanāya saddhiṃ balakāyena;
snp3.7:7.1.eng: “There is no marriage, Sela, and the king is not coming.

snp3.7:7.2.pli: api ca kho me mahāyañño paccupaṭṭhito.
snp3.7:7.2.eng: Rather, I am setting up a big sacrifice.

snp3.7:7.3.pli: Atthi samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito aṅguttarāpesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi āpaṇaṃ anuppatto.
snp3.7:7.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.

snp3.7:7.5.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

snp3.7:7.6.pli: So me nimantito svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
snp3.7:7.6.eng: He has been invited by me for tomorrow’s meal together with the mendicant Saṅgha.”

snp3.7:7.7.eng: “Worthy Keṇiya, did you say ‘the awakened one’?”
snp3.7:7.7.comm: Anāthapiṇḍika responded in the same way when hearing of the Buddha (Kd 16:4.2.10). Also compare Bāvari’s elation at Snp 5.1:19.1.

snp3.7:7.9.eng: “Worthy Keṇiya, did you say ‘the awakened one’?”

snp3.7:8.2.pli: “ghosopi kho eso dullabho lokasmiṃ, yadidaṃ buddhoti.
snp3.7:8.2.eng: “It’s hard to even find the word ‘awakened one’ in the world.

snp3.7:8.3.pli: Āgatāni kho panamhākaṃ mantesu dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.
snp3.7:8.3.eng: The thirty-two marks of a great man have been handed down in our hymns. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.

snp3.7:8.4.pli: Sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
snp3.7:8.4.eng: If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures.

snp3.7:8.5.eng: He has the following seven treasures:

snp3.7:8.6.pli: cakkaratanaṃ, hatthiratanaṃ, assaratanaṃ, maṇiratanaṃ, itthiratanaṃ, gahapatiratanaṃ, pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṃ.
snp3.7:8.6.eng: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.

snp3.7:8.7.pli: Parosahassaṃ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
snp3.7:8.7.eng: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

snp3.7:8.8.pli: So imaṃ pathaviṃ sāgarapariyantaṃ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
snp3.7:8.8.eng: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.

snp3.7:8.9.pli: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati, arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.
snp3.7:8.9.eng: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who has cast off the world’s veil.

snp3.7:8.10.pli: Kahaṃ pana, bho keṇiya, etarahi so bhavaṃ gotamo viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho”ti?
snp3.7:8.10.eng: “But Keṇiya, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

snp3.7:9.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, keṇiyo jaṭilo dakkhiṇaṃ bāhuṃ paggahetvā selaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.7:9.1.eng: When he said this, Keṇiya pointed with his right arm and said,

snp3.7:9.2.eng: “There, worthy Sela, at that line of blue forest.”

snp3.7:9.3.pli: Atha kho selo brāhmaṇo tīhi māṇavakasatehi saddhiṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
snp3.7:9.3.eng: Then Sela, together with his young students, approached the Buddha.

snp3.7:9.4.pli: Atha kho selo brāhmaṇo te māṇavake āmantesi:
snp3.7:9.4.eng: He said to his young students,

snp3.7:9.6.pli: Durāsadā hi te bhagavanto sīhāva ekacarā.
snp3.7:9.6.eng: For the Buddhas are intimidating, like a lion living alone.
snp3.7:9.6.comm: Durāsada (“intimidating”) is also at AN 4.42:4.1, which shows that the sense is that they are hard to defeat in debate.

snp3.7:9.7.pli: Yadā cāhaṃ, bho, samaṇena gotamena saddhiṃ manteyyaṃ, mā me bhonto antarantarā kathaṃ opātetha;
snp3.7:9.7.eng: When I’m consulting with the ascetic Gotama, don’t interrupt.

snp3.7:10.1.pli: Atha kho selo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
snp3.7:10.1.eng: Then Sela went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

snp3.7:10.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
snp3.7:10.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.

snp3.7:10.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho selo brāhmaṇo bhagavato kāye dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni samannesi.
snp3.7:10.3.eng: and scrutinized the Buddha’s body for the thirty-two marks of a great man.

snp3.7:10.4.pli: Addasā kho selo brāhmaṇo bhagavato kāye dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni yebhuyyena ṭhapetvā dve.
snp3.7:10.4.eng: He saw all of them except for two,

snp3.7:10.5.pli: Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati—

snp3.7:10.6.eng: whether the private parts were covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.

snp3.7:11.1.eng: Then it occurred to the Buddha,

snp3.7:11.2.pli: “passati kho me ayaṃ selo brāhmaṇo dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni yebhuyyena ṭhapetvā dve.
snp3.7:11.2.eng: “Sela sees all the marks except for two,

snp3.7:11.3.pli: Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati—

snp3.7:11.4.eng: whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.”

snp3.7:11.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi, yathā addasa selo brāhmaṇo bhagavato kosohitaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ.
snp3.7:11.5.eng: The Buddha used his psychic power to will that Sela would see his private parts covered in a foreskin.

snp3.7:11.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā jivhaṃ ninnāmetvā ubhopi kaṇṇasotāni anumasi paṭimasi, ubhopi nāsikasotāni anumasi paṭimasi, kevalampi nalāṭamaṇḍalaṃ jivhāya chādesi.
snp3.7:11.6.eng: And he stuck out his tongue and stroked back and forth on his ear holes and nostrils, and covered his entire forehead with his tongue.

snp3.7:12.2.pli: “samannāgato kho samaṇo gotamo dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi paripuṇṇehi, no aparipuṇṇehi.
snp3.7:12.2.eng: “The ascetic Gotama possesses the thirty-two marks completely, lacking none.

snp3.7:12.3.pli: No ca kho naṃ jānāmi buddho vā no vā.
snp3.7:12.3.eng: But I don’t know whether or not he is an awakened one.

snp3.7:12.4.pli: Sutaṃ kho pana metaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ vuḍḍhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
snp3.7:12.4.eng: I have heard that brahmins of the past who were elderly and senior, the tutors of tutors, said,

snp3.7:12.5.pli: ‘ye te bhavanti arahanto sammāsambuddhā, te sake vaṇṇe bhaññamāne attānaṃ pātukarontī’ti.
snp3.7:12.5.eng: ‘Those who are perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas reveal themselves when praised.’
snp3.7:12.5.comm: This idea is not found elsewhere in the Pali.

snp3.7:12.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthaveyyan”ti.
snp3.7:12.6.eng: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”

snp3.7:12.7.pli: Atha kho selo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthavi:
snp3.7:12.7.eng: Then Sela extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:

snp3.7:13.2.eng: you’re radiant, handsome, lovely to behold;

snp3.7:13.4.eng: with teeth so white; you’re strong.

snp3.7:14.3.eng: the marks of a great man,

snp3.7:14.4.eng: are all found on your body.

snp3.7:15.1.eng: Your eyes are clear, your face is fair,

snp3.7:15.3.eng: In the midst of the Saṅgha of ascetics,

snp3.7:16.1.eng: You’re a mendicant fine to see,

snp3.7:16.2.eng: with skin that shines like lustrous gold.

snp3.7:16.4.eng: what do you want with the ascetic life?

snp3.7:17.1.eng: You’re fit to be a king,

snp3.7:17.2.eng: a wheel-turning monarch, chief of charioteers,

snp3.7:17.4.eng: lord of the Black Plum Tree Land.

snp3.7:18.4.eng: as king of kings, lord of mankind!”

snp3.7:19.2.comm: While the content of the text is identical with MN 92, the current text has more tags identifying the speakers.

snp3.7:19.4.eng: By the teaching I roll forth the wheel

snp3.7:19.5.comm: This is of course a reference to the first sermon (SN 56.11).

snp3.7:21.1.comm: The title “General of the Dhamma” belongs to Sāriputta (Ud 2.8:16.2, Thag 18.1:33.1).

snp3.7:21.2.eng: the disciple who follows the Teacher’s way?

snp3.7:21.4.eng: of the teaching you rolled forth?”

snp3.7:22.1.eng: “By me the wheel was rolled forth,”

snp3.7:22.4.eng: Sāriputta, taking after the Realized One,

snp3.7:22.5.comm: Anujāta is said at Iti 74:4.1 to be a child who “takes after” the good qualities of their parents.

snp3.7:23.1.eng: I have known what should be known,

snp3.7:23.2.eng: and developed what should be developed,

snp3.7:23.3.eng: and given up what should be given up:

snp3.7:23.4.eng: and so, brahmin, I am a Buddha.

snp3.7:24.4.comm: Abhiṇhaso means “repeatedly”. Here the force of the saying is, I think, “It is hard enough to encounter a Buddha even once, let alone repeatedly.”

snp3.7:25.3.eng: one of those whose appearance in the world

snp3.7:26.4.eng: I rejoice, fearing nothing from any quarter.”

snp3.7:27.2.eng: is spoken by the Clear-eyed One.

snp3.7:27.4.eng: roars like a lion in the jungle.

snp3.7:28.3.eng: who would not be inspired by him,

snp3.7:28.4.eng: even one born in a dark class?
snp3.7:28.4.comm: The “dark class” refers to those born in an unfortunate state (AN 6.57:11.1). Sela is saying that the Buddha’s path is for everyone, not just the fortunate.

snp3.7:29.1.eng: Those who wish may follow me;

snp3.7:29.3.eng: Right here, I’ll go forth in his presence,

snp3.7:29.4.eng: the one of such outstanding wisdom.”

snp3.7:30.3.eng: we’ll also go forth in his presence,

snp3.7:30.4.eng: the one of such outstanding wisdom.”

snp3.7:31.2.eng: with joined palms held up, ask:

snp3.7:32.3.eng: “apparent in the present life, immediately effective.

snp3.7:32.4.eng: Here the going forth isn’t in vain

snp3.7:32.5.eng: for one who trains with diligence.”

snp3.7:33.1.pli: Alattha kho selo brāhmaṇo sapariso bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
snp3.7:33.1.eng: And the brahmin Sela together with his assembly received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

snp3.7:33.2.pli: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo tassā rattiyā accayena sake assame paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocāpesi:
snp3.7:33.2.eng: And when the night had passed Keṇiya had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own hermitage. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,

snp3.7:33.3.eng: “It’s time, worthy Gotama, the meal is ready.”

snp3.7:33.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena keṇiyassa jaṭilassa assamo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena.
snp3.7:33.4.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Keṇiya’s hermitage, where he sat on the seat spread out, together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.

snp3.7:34.1.pli: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
snp3.7:34.1.eng: Then Keṇiya served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

snp3.7:34.2.pli: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
snp3.7:34.2.eng: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Keṇiya took a low seat and sat to one side.

snp3.7:34.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho keṇiyaṃ jaṭilaṃ bhagavā imāhi gāthāhi anumodi:
snp3.7:34.3.eng: The Buddha expressed his appreciation with these verses:

snp3.7:35.1.eng: “The foremost of sacrifices <j>is the offering to the sacred flame;
snp3.7:35.1.comm: Mukha means originally “mouth”, hence “opening”, “entrance”; but also “face”, hence “front”, “foremost”. The fire is the foremost sacrifice, but fire is also a “mouth”, since “however much one may put into a fire, it burns it all up all” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 5.14.8). This sense of “consume” or “subsume” is alive in these verses as well. For example, the Sāvitrī “subsumes” other hymns, for merely one line is equivalent to all three Vedas (BU 5.14.2). The sense of mukha as “entrance, introduction” also applies, since the fire sacrifice and the Sāvitrī are the things first learned by a new student (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.4.12). Fire is also the “first” creation, and hence the oldest of rituals (ŚB 6.1.1.11).  | Yaññā is a truncated genitive plural (“of sacrifices”).

snp3.7:35.2.eng: the Sāvitrī is the foremost of prayer;
snp3.7:35.2.comm: The Sāvitrī is a famous verse recited daily by brahmin priests at dawn: “Might we make our own that desirable effulgence of god Savitar, who will rouse forth our insights (Rig Veda 3.62.10, Jamison/Brereton). It was the “head” of metres (śiro gāyatryaḥ, ŚB 8.6.2.3, 8.6.2.6), and was “praised as the foremost of recitations” (gāyatrāṇy uktha mukhanai śaṁsanti, Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa 17.7.1). “Prayers”, furthermore, are born “from the mouth” (mukhato, ŚB 11.5.4.17). The Sāvitrī is the chief exponent of the gāyatrī metre, by which it is sometimes known. The three-lined gāyatrī is the “first” of poetic styles, both technically—as it is the shortest from which others were derived (ŚB 1.3.4.6, 1.6.2.10)—and historically, as it dominated the Rig Veda but fell out of fashion later. | Chandas can be either “meter” in general, or a metrical song of praise, especially a Vedic hymn (eg. ŚB 11.5.7.3). The Sāvitrī is a Vedic text, not a meter, so the latter meaning must apply here. It is a collective singular.

snp3.7:35.3.eng: of humans, the king is the foremost;

snp3.7:35.4.eng: the ocean’s the foremost of rivers;

snp3.7:36.1.eng: the foremost of stars is the moon;

snp3.7:36.2.eng: the sun is the foremost of blazes;

snp3.7:36.3.eng: for those who sacrifice seeking merit,

snp3.7:37.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā keṇiyaṃ jaṭilaṃ imāhi gāthāhi anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
snp3.7:37.1.eng: When the Buddha had expressed his appreciation to Keṇiya the matted-hair ascetic with these verses, he got up from his seat and left.

snp3.7:37.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā selo sapariso eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva …pe…
snp3.7:37.2.eng: Then Venerable Sela and his assembly, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. They lived having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

snp3.7:37.3.pli: aññataro kho panāyasmā selo sapariso arahataṃ ahosi.
snp3.7:37.3.eng: And Venerable Sela together with his assembly became perfected.

snp3.7:38.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā selo sapariso yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā ekaṃsaṃ cīvaraṃ katvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
snp3.7:38.1.eng: Then Sela with his assembly went to see the Buddha. He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

snp3.7:39.2.eng: we went for refuge, O Clear-eyed One.

snp3.7:39.3.eng: In these seven days, Blessed One,

snp3.7:39.4.eng: we’ve become tamed in your teaching.

snp3.7:40.1.eng: You are the Buddha, you are the Teacher,
snp3.7:40.1.comm: This verse and the next are also at Snp 3.6:49.1.

snp3.7:40.2.eng: you are the sage who has overcome Māra;

snp3.7:40.3.eng: you have cut off the underlying tendencies,

snp3.7:40.4.eng: you’ve crossed over, and you bring humanity across.

snp3.7:41.3.eng: you are a lion, free of grasping,

snp3.7:41.4.eng: with fear and dread given up.

snp3.7:42.3.eng: Stretch out your feet, great hero:

snp3.7:42.4.eng: let these giants bow to the Teacher.”
